Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Hidden Side of Rapidly Growing Black Holes: Host Masses and Evolution of Obscured Quasars with SDSS and WISE
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to combine data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and the Wide-Field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) to provide a high-precision measurement of the spatial clustering of obscured quasars. The scientific objective is to establish if the obscured QSO population has a different origin from unobscured QSOs, for example if they live in larger dark matter halos. This may lead to important new probes Dark Matter Halo structures and the evolution of galaxies.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate students, and outreach to middle-school teachers via summer workshops in collaboration with the Department of Secondary Education at the University of Wyoming, with the primary goal of increasing the quality of middle- and secondary-level physics education in Wyoming and New Hampshire.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this program was based on using powerful new astronomical data sets to understand the supermassive black holes that reside at the centers of galaxies. In particular, we wished to understand how these black holes grow and change over the history of the Universe, with a focus on the dust-obscured rapidly-growing black holes ("quasars") that have only recently been detected in large numbers with observatories that operate at mid-infrared wavelengths. One important clue as to the nature of obscured black holes comes from how they are clustered together in space, which allows us to determine the masses of the dark matter halos in which they reside. In some theoretical models, some quasars are only seen as obscured because we are viewing them from particular direction (the "orientation" model), while other models suggest that obscuration happens during an important phase in the formation of galaxies associated with rapid star formation (the "evolutionary" model).

In this NSF research program we performed some of the first clustering measurements of obscured quasars that allow us to distinguish between these two scenarios. We focused on using data from the Wide-Field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) and Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), as well as a number of other ground- and space-based telescopes.

Our work has confirmed that obscured quasars are more strongly clustered than unobscured quasars, providing support for the quasar evolutionary model. However, we found that the magnitude of this difference is smaller than obtained in previous studies, due to improvements in our handling of complex effects in the WISE data. We have also verified this result by developing a new technique for measuring dark matter halos through the gravitational lensing of the cosmic microwave background. To interpret these clustering results, we have extensively characterized the physical characteristics of obscured quasars using a range of observations, allowing us to understand the radiative power of these quasars and how deeply buried they are behind the obscured material.

The results of this work have so far been disseminated in 15 articles in major journals and through 10 conference presentations. Our new WISE data masks (handling the complex effects in the data) have been made available online to the scientific community.

The broader impacts of this program were based on training teachers to include astronomical concepts in their curricula. Through this collaborative grant we organized three teacher training workshops in Laramie, Wyoming that reached 50 teachers from Wyoming and New Hampshire, the states that are home to our two institutions (the University of Wyoming and Dartmouth College). These workshops were based on learning hands-on activities and developing inquiry-based lesson plans for use in classrooms. Materials and activities from these workshops have been made freely available online.

This grant contributed to the professional training of Dartmouth postdoctoral researcher Kevin Hainline, who is now using these skills working on the team for the upcoming James Webb Space Telescope. This research also comprised part of the PhD thesis work of Dartmouth graduate students Christopher Carroll and Chien-Ting Chen, who completed his PhD in spring 2015 and is now serving as a postdoctoral researcher at Penn State University.
